I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
Living in a big city, my neighborhood is like a patchwork quilt of different areas. Homes are scattered throughout, sometimes tucked right between busy shops and offices. There's a ton of places to eat – from fancy restaurants to cozy cafes – and a whole bunch of stores, too. You've got your big brand names, but there's also a growing number of cute little boutiques popping up everywhere.  They're not just in shopping malls anymore, they're lining the streets, bringing a bit of life to quieter neighborhoods.  

There are a couple of parks nearby, and it's common to see families enjoying the green spaces with their kids.  Speaking of people, my neighborhood is a melting pot!  You've got the LGBTQ+ community, a strong Orthodox Jewish presence, and lots of newcomers from the former Soviet Union.  Venturing a bit further out, you'll find even more diversity, with pockets of Korean, Chinese, and Armenian communities just a stone's throw away.  But even those short distances can feel like a long drive in this city – traffic jams are legendary, especially during rush hour.  Most people here rely on their cars, so walking isn't really an option, which makes the traffic even worse.  Finding a parking spot can feel like a treasure hunt!  

Ironically, despite the traffic woes, there's been a building boom lately.  Towering apartment buildings are sprouting up everywhere, making the city even more crowded.  Some residents are worried about the influx of new people and the added congestion.

But there's still a variety of housing options.  Not everyone wants to live in a giant apartment building.  You've got houses of all sizes, smaller apartment complexes, and even duplexes scattered throughout.  My neighborhood itself is a mix of folks of all ages, and to be honest, I don't know most of my neighbors. Back in my childhood, things felt different.  We played outside all the time with kids from the neighborhood.  Those were simpler times.

My neighborhood holds a unique charm.  While most houses are single-family dwellings, some have been cleverly split into two separate units, all while remaining connected. My own home boasts a modest front yard and a small driveway to the side.  It, like many others, whispers of a bygone era when suburban living represented the quintessential American dream.  This dream, once so universally embraced, now seems to be retreating, pulling away from the grasp of those who once held it dear. Yet, my neighborhood, along with countless others, still stands as a testament to this fading dream, a beacon of hope for those who cling to its fading allure.  

The residents, however, seem less optimistic than they once were.  The meticulous upkeep of the little yards has dwindled, a reflection of the shifting tides of time.  Yet, the sight of a car or two in every driveway remains a constant, a reminder of life's persevering rhythm. Children, oblivious to the world's complexities, still frolic in the streets, their laughter echoing the innocence of a simpler time.

The neighborhood's heart beats within the walls of a public school, a venerable institution that has stood for nearly nine decades. It continues to inspire hope in the younger generation while evoking nostalgic memories in the older residents.  Although churches are few and far between, their pews mostly empty, the basketball courts remain a vibrant hub of activity. Each house, though distinct in its appearance, carries a shared sense of belonging, a common thread woven through the tapestry of the neighborhood.

A large supermarket, aptly named "Super A," has been a mainstay for generations, its ownership entrusted to a Yemeni family, a rare splash of diversity in a predominantly African-American community.  The streets, wide and inviting, are often transformed into impromptu football fields, where children chase after the ball, their laughter filling the air.  The cars that pass by are met with a momentary pause, a silent acknowledgment of shared space.

Most residents have called this neighborhood home for generations, their stories woven into its fabric. Tales of a time when everyone knew each other, when community was a cherished value, still linger in the air.  A karate school, once a haven for aspiring martial artists, has transformed into a pharmacy, reflecting perhaps a societal shift in priorities.  A small movie theater, showcasing classic films at discounted prices, stands as a haven for the older generation, offering a respite from the relentless onslaught of new releases.

A single expressway cuts through the town, its entrance and exit situated in the neighboring town. Once, a petition to establish a local exit was initiated, supported by the younger generation who craved easier access.  However, the older residents, fearing the disruption to the neighborhood's tranquility, persuaded the city council to reject the proposal.  

A new high school is currently under construction, and the community is engaged in a spirited debate over its mascot.  I, for one, believe a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would perfectly embody the unique spirit of my town - a blend of tradition and innovation, a reflection of a community that strives to preserve its roots while embracing the future.

This neighborhood might seem unassuming at first glance. Tucked behind a shopping strip in a residential area, it's not the kind of place you'd expect to find thriving communities. But venture past the old, abandoned Whole Foods and behind the seasonal hotels, and you'll discover a hidden world.  

A line of apartment complexes, like carefully disassembled Russian nesting dolls laid side-by-side, stretches down the road. Some have been in the news for less-than-pleasant reasons, but don't let appearances fool you. The complexes beside those, though, hold a secret known only to a few outsiders.  

Across from these hidden apartments lies a quiet community college satellite campus, a haven for sleepy students sipping coffee and yawning at 7 a.m. Iron gates creak open, admitting them one by one, while impatient commuters grumble at the traffic delays.

The road forks into another residential street, where a park and a rehabilitation center stand side-by-side. The center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazy ceiling fan churning the warm summer air. Children frolic in the park, their laughter echoing through the air as they cartwheel and spin amidst the tall green grass. Old folks stroll their dogs, occasionally scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards, while young girls huddle by the playground, whispering secrets and giggling about boys and the latest online trends.

A nearby strip mall offers a variety of delights: a sushi place with affordable eats, a swimming supply store, a nail salon, and even a frozen yogurt shop where teenagers indulge their sweet cravings while performing daring skateboard tricks.  

This neighborhood is a snapshot of Americana, a timeless slice of the sleepy South where life moves at its own pace.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past fields of corn stretching as far as the eye could see. I knew she'd be taken aback by the vast emptiness of the landscape.  She was from a town where you could walk to the grocery store in five minutes - she'd never seen this much open space before.  Overwhelmed by the endless rows of corn, I told her about growing up in rural Ohio.  In that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from.

We continued down a two-lane country road.  Soon, we passed a quarry filled with water, and just beyond it was the small development where I live. The houses were mostly brick and stucco, each sitting on at least half an acre of land that everyone took pride in keeping up.  In the spring, colorful flowers bloomed alongside the midwestern trees that changed with each season.  The driveways were filled with gleaming Mercedes-Benz luxury cars, polished to perfection after a good wash.

As we drove closer to my grey stucco home, we passed my Korean neighbor, always smiling and waving. He spent his days meticulously mowing his lawn, his singing voice echoing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood teased him about it, but he was a kind man with a fascinating past. He used to be a doctor, but now he blended in seamlessly with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower.

Finally, we reached my house.  Geese wandered around the side yard, chased by our energetic Terrier. Out back, a small stream flowed into the quarry, filled with the sounds of bullfrogs, running water, and the occasional moo from nearby farms.  Across a hand-built wooden bridge lay an untouched oasis, a haven of naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent most of my childhood, building tree forts, chasing animals, and making lifelong friends.

The winters in my small town were harsh, but incredibly beautiful. The yard transformed from a lush green into a stark wilderness. The trees that once wore vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers became bare skeletons of bark. When snow fell, it created a winter wonderland overnight. Snow angels and snowmen dotted the backyard, remnants of playful battles between my sister and me. We were fierce opponents, armed with snowballs and branches, building igloo-like forts to defend our territory. In that frozen wonderland, we escaped into our own little world, where childhood worries melted away.

To truly grasp Portland, Oregon, you've got to understand its unique brand of "weird."  It's more than just a quirky slogan plastered on a building that somehow manages to be a pizzeria, bar, music venue, and strip club all in one.  It's a reflection of the city's soul, a reminder of its past and a promise to those who seek something different. For some, it's a nostalgic yearning for the Portland of yesteryear, a time before it gained national recognition and became more expensive.  A time when creative subcultures thrived in the shadows, embracing the unconventional. For others, it's an open invitation: come to Portland, where being different isn't just accepted, it's celebrated.

Despite the influx of wealthier residents from California and the constant construction of high-rises to house them, Portland's core identity remains intact. It's a city where you'll find a blend of the familiar and the extraordinary.  We have yoga studios and hipster coffee shops, just like any other modern city. But we also have something more: a spirit of acceptance that extends to the unconventional and the unexpected.  

One of the most enchanting aspects of Portland is its "free boxes." These cardboard (or sometimes plastic) treasure troves appear on sidewalks throughout the city, filled with discarded items that become someone else's hidden gem. You might find clothes, books, or even something truly unique, a reminder that even in the midst of urban life, there's always a touch of magic to be discovered.

Portland's charm lies in its diversity, its willingness to embrace all its quirks and contradictions. We have people who find joy in goat yoga, others who cheer for the Timbers soccer team, and still others who prefer to lose themselves in the city's vibrant nightlife.

We're not immune to the challenges facing many cities. Drug addiction and homelessness are issues we grapple with, fueled by complex social and economic factors. But even in the face of these difficulties, Portlanders show resilience and a deep-rooted sense of community.

At its heart, Portland is a city that encourages you to be yourself, to embrace your passions, and to never take life too seriously.  It's a place where "weird" isn't just a word, it's a way of life.

The mountains stand as silent sentinels, ever-present in the north. They watch over the sun's daily dance, a constant reminder of time's passage, regardless of my own preoccupations. Though I might forget them amidst the chaos of work and life, they remain, unyielding and steadfast. On days when stress threatens to overwhelm me, they beckon me to turn towards them. In their presence, I find solace, a sense of strength to carry on, one step at a time.

My journey with these mountains began during my university years. They captivated me from the first moment I laid eyes on them, those majestic peaks north of campus. The university itself, with its charming buildings, tranquil ponds, and vibrant trees, holds a special place in my heart. But the mountains reign supreme, casting a spell that no other location can match.

The town itself is a tapestry of beauty. Quaint cafés, buzzing with the energy of late-night study sessions, dot the landscape. A short walk or bus ride leads to the downtown area, where faded brick facades whisper tales of a bygone era. Restaurants and offices stand shoulder to shoulder, radiating a vibrant energy that rivals its neighboring city. However, this urban pulse fades quickly, giving way to the tranquil charm of small-town life just beyond the library. This juxtaposition of atmospheres, so close together, creates a unique allure, beckoning exploration and the creation of cherished memories.

I've built countless memories here—walking past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter, sprinting through the bustling downtown to catch a movie in the university's fancy theater. Yet, like any place, it also holds its share of painful memories. The ponds, in particular, have witnessed my quiet moments of reflection, as well as tear-stained cries in the dead of night during existential crises.

One such night, watching turtles, ducks, and insects going about their lives, I found myself pondering my own purpose, struggling to decipher the complexities of life. I walked past the pond, the park, and the quintessential suburban houses, eventually reaching a main street. As the sun painted the sky in shades of gold and blue, I realized I was walking north.

There they were, the mountains, unwavering and steadfast. They pierced the horizon, their presence more imposing than any building. In that moment, their silent strength stirred within me a sense of perseverance, a reminder to keep moving forward.

Planning a trip to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn? Finding your way around won't be a challenge!  With its excellent public transportation, a staple in New York City, you'll easily navigate this vibrant urban neighborhood.  Get ready for a sensory experience, as Bensonhurst has blossomed into a hub of Asian culture over the past two decades. You'll stumble upon Asian-owned shops on nearly every block, from bustling supermarkets to convenient laundromats. Local residents adore these businesses, drawn to their high-quality goods, reasonable prices, and unmatched convenience. Just a stone's throw from where I am, four Asian supermarkets stand within a mere two minutes' walk of each other, showcasing the area's dedication to accessibility. 

While Asian culture thrives in Bensonhurst, the neighborhood radiates diversity, welcoming immigrants and their American-born children.  Beyond the Asian-owned businesses, a recently revitalized park offers recreation for all. It boasts ten basketball courts, a spacious field perfect for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for the little ones, and even a water fountain to beat the summer heat.  

Unlike some parts of New York City, Bensonhurst is primarily residential.  You'll find charming two-family houses dotting the landscape, alongside co-op buildings and condominiums.  The residents here are generally friendly, though their exuberance can sometimes translate to a bit of noise.  Expect car engines roaring and music blasting as cars cruise by, occasionally rousing you from your slumber.

When venturing out at night, it's wise to remain vigilant. While Bensonhurst is generally safe, like any urban area, it's important to be aware of your surroundings.  Unfortunately, instances of petty crime, such as theft and harassment, can occur.  I've personally experienced bullying in the past, though that was several years ago.  Recently, package theft has also become a concern.

One final note: despite New York City's regulations regarding pet waste, it seems some residents haven't quite caught on.  Prepare to encounter dog droppings on your daily outings.  Keep your shoes clean and tread carefully!

Life here is a bit of an uphill climb, literally. My house sits atop the steepest hill in the neighborhood, a place nicknamed "workout hill" by the joggers who conquer its slopes daily.  Sidewalks are scarce, so everyone walks along the road, which is a bit rough in places.  The old telephone and electric wires strung around the block look tattered, a testament to the frequent storms that bring down branches and debris.  The constant repairs leave them looking patched and mismatched.

Everywhere you look, towering evergreen trees dominate the landscape. But locals aren't fond of them. They strive to remove as many as possible, as the trees block the view of the ocean.  That's why so many houses perch high on the hill, boasting large, glass-fronted second stories that reach for the breathtaking vistas of the bay. Sunsets are a sight to behold, painting the water with an ethereal glow as the sky erupts in fiery hues of orange.  However, most days are shrouded in a misty haze, filtering the sunlight and casting an overcast, damp spell over the neighborhood.

Moss thrives in this environment, clinging to roofs, cars, and even railings. I once left my car parked in the driveway for a month, only to return to a fuzzy green coat of moss that took hours to scrub off.

Children are scarce here. While a school is just a few blocks away, the neighborhood is mostly populated by older residents, many of them retired. Dogs, rather than children, roam the streets, often seen lounging in lawns or chasing each other down the road. Leaving a door or window open invites unwanted canine visitors, as I discovered when a curious dog snuck into my living room.

Rabbits are another common sight, much to the chagrin of gardeners who find them digging up their plants and lawns. My cats, however, delight in the chase, having largely eradicated them from our immediate vicinity. The usual assortment of birds also grace the area, from tiny sparrows and hummingbirds to the occasional hawk or eagle, until they are chased off by the neighborhood crows.

There are no shops nearby, but a short hike downhill to the waterfront reveals a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. The beach itself is minimal, but the rocky shore offers a fun pastime of launching stones into the water. The bay is narrow, allowing clear views of the opposite shoreline even through the persistent mist.

Our little corner of Tennessee is a typical suburb, nestled between two state highways.  While the traffic flow is a bit more than I'd prefer, it's still a peaceful neighborhood.  Folks here tend to keep to themselves, mostly tending to their yards and everyday routines. There's a sense of familiarity, as not many newcomers pass through.  In the winter, the kids on our street turn a nearby hill into a sledding haven.  We live at the front corner, so we have a front-row seat to the neighborhood's daily happenings. We recognize most vehicles that rumble by, and any unfamiliar ones catch our attention.  You'll often see folks out walking, either for exercise or strolling their dogs. Kids whiz by on bicycles, and the usual suburban sights and sounds fill the air.

Since we work from home, we spend a good deal of time inside our house.  It's just the four of us: my wife, myself, and our two daughters, eleven and fourteen years old.  They're used to our comings and goings, just as we are with theirs.  Rain or shine, we make an effort to get outside and play.  There are evenings when the scent of barbecue fills the air as we fire up the grill on our back deck. The sound of lawnmowers is a constant melody from March until October, a reminder that the grass never seems to stop growing.  

We're surrounded by trees, a legacy of the neighborhood's wooded past. They provide ample shade, but come autumn, we're faced with the annual ritual of raking and burning leaves, a fragrant sign that fall has arrived.  This year, we've been experiencing a rather long fall, as winter has been less than impressive.  

Our garage is at the back of the house, so we rarely use the front door unless someone knocks, which isn't often.  Working on my truck or other projects in the garage is a way for me to feel connected to the neighborhood. Holidays bring a bit more activity. Thanksgiving sees families hosting out-of-town visitors, with cars spilling onto our quiet streets.  Mother's Day and Christmas bring a similar buzz.

Overall, it's a pleasant place to call home. If it weren't for the constant flow of traffic, it would be absolutely perfect.

My neighborhood is smack dab in the heart of the high desert, where dirt seems to be the only thing that grows.  Unless you've actually lived here, it's hard to understand the constant feeling of brown, and finding a lawn means someone's dropping serious cash on upkeep. Back in the 90s, when I first lived here, houses were spread miles apart.  Now, it's getting more crowded, but still not as packed as those big cities.  Honestly, it feels like the desert is turning into a city every day, though I guess that's happening everywhere.

For the most part, the people here are friendly, just like anywhere else, you've got your good and bad apples.  My neighborhood is surrounded by kind older folks, so maybe that's why it feels a bit nicer.  When it comes to shopping, it's mostly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final.  If you want a fancier grocery store, you've got to head out of town.  I don't see any Whole Foods or anything like that around here.

Based on what I see, construction seems to be the biggest industry in our city. I guess it's because we still have tons of open space to build on.  That part scares me a little. I left a big city to get away from that, and I don't want it to become like that again. Speaking of construction, that's where I work full-time. I'm a drywall and T-bar installer.


What I love most about living here is the wildlife. People come to the high desert for many reasons, one of them being the stark beauty of it all. The harsh desert climate and landscape create unique ecosystems that need protection and are home to all sorts of amazing creatures. We should all learn about these animal neighbors and how to live alongside them peacefully. My family has adapted really well to the wildlife. My three kids are obsessed with lizards and desert bugs. As I'm writing this, they're outside trying to catch different ones.

As for things to do, we have a few attractions. Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert in a unique way. If you're visiting, try to time it with the annual San Bernardino County Fair – it's a blast!  You can also take a trip to nearby Wrightwood to see the snow-capped mountains and try some winter sports.  

If you're interested in the history and culture of the high desert, check out the Victor Valley Museum. They have all sorts of cool stuff – fossils, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of how our city grew.

Describing my neighborhood is a bit unusual, I think. While most people might picture traditional houses and families, my "hood" is the college campus I call home. My dorm building and its residents are my immediate community, and the wider campus is my extended neighborhood.  Though my situation is unique, there are some familiar elements. Like any neighborhood, mine has its own "houses," people, shops, and even a park. Let's start with the "houses."

There are three main types: apartments, regular houses that anyone affiliated with the school can rent, and dorm buildings. Apartments typically house 4-6 rooms per floor, with 2-4 people per room, making each building home to about 20 people. Then there are the regular houses, mostly 2-4 bedrooms, often occupied by alumni. These are less common but scattered throughout the campus. Finally, there are the massive dorm buildings, the most populous type, with hundreds of students sharing rooms in pairs.

My school is incredibly diverse, and that diversity is reflected in its residents. People from all walks of life live here, with faculty mostly in the houses, newer students in dorms, and older students in apartments. 

Words can't fully capture the vibrant tapestry of personalities that make up this neighborhood. Let's move on to the amenities. 

Since the campus is essentially its own mini-city, it has a variety of stores, including dining options, unique school-branded shops, and even grocery stores, ensuring everything you need is just a short walk away. And of course, there's the park, a place where everyone comes together, kept safe and clean by the community itself.

Ten years have flown by since I first set foot in this neighborhood. Moving from Riverdale to Stockbridge was a bittersweet experience. Leaving my loved ones in Riverdale brought tears to my eyes, but my parents believed this move would offer a brighter future with better housing, a stronger high school, and a safer environment.  As time passed, I adjusted to my new surroundings, forging new friendships and, of course, encountering a few rivals along the way.

While I didn't become close with most neighbors, Mr. Glen and his family, along with Dennis, who lived right next door, felt more like family. I cherish their company and the memories we've shared. Their wedding, a joyous celebration, stands out vividly. Witnessing their love and happiness made me dream of a future where I could provide the same level of love and care for my future wife.  I even caught the garter during their reception!  I remember dancing the night away with Marsharii, one of their daughters.  I hope she's doing well and pursuing her dreams.

The neighborhood itself feels like a labyrinth, but thankfully, I now have a GPS to help me navigate.  I've explored some parts with my friends, Kason and Curtis, who were always up for adventure and a good time. We spent countless hours engaging in video games and simply enjoying life to the fullest.  

Finding solace in nature, I often visited the park, where the tranquility and serenity calmed my soul.  Sometimes, I'd bring sticks from the hardware store to practice my balance and even my bokken, a wooden sword, when I could. Engaging in these activities brought me joy and a sense of fulfillment.

Although I haven't played tennis or basketball in a while, the courts remain a reminder of past fun times. My dad, along with Mr. Graves, instilled a love for tennis in me and my best friend. They pushed us hard, but the memories we made were priceless.

Looking back, I realize this neighborhood has been a tapestry woven with laughter, friendship, and personal growth.  There are countless stories etched in its streets, and I'm excited for the adventures that lie ahead!

My neighborhood's a real mixed bag, right near my college which is a huge plus.  Mostly apartments, a few decent, budget-friendly restaurants and bars - though one recently got a fancy makeover and jacked up their prices, but the service and drinks are still okay.  Everyone around here is either a student or has a tighter budget, just like me. There are tons of kids because of the elementary school down the street.  I keep to myself, don't really know my neighbors. They're a bit of a wild bunch,  always puffing on that good good, so the building management put an air freshener right outside their door – hilarious, like they're trying to mask the smell.  Most of the buildings around here are older, might have been gussied up inside though.  Down the road, they've got these brand new apartments, but I wouldn't touch them with a ten-foot pole. Cheaply built, but the rent is sky-high, taking advantage of the "near campus" premium.  Then there's this hole-in-the-wall diner, cheap eats, paper plates, mostly microwaved,  right next to a gas station that I hear is a nightmare to work at.  But hey, the city spruced up the road last year – new sidewalk, grass everywhere,  it's actually looking pretty decent now. My building is tucked away under a canopy of trees, they chopped down a few, but there are still plenty.  Behind us is another tree line, then another apartment complex. 42nd Street, where I live, is okay, but 43rd Street behind it? Not so much. Sidewalks are crumbling, buildings look like they're about to fall apart.  Lots of trees there too, probably trying to hide the ugliness. Most of the crime around here seems to be happening at a complex on 43rd Street, but honestly, there are some shady characters in other buildings too.  But you know what? I kind of like it here. Can't beat the price, got everything I need close by. Walking distance to the university, two bus stops, easy access to everything.

My neighborhood is a charming collection of duplexes arranged on a cul-de-sac, spaced out so they resemble individual houses.  Every dwelling sports a sunny yellow exterior, adorned with white porches and vibrant green metal roofs.  While not everyone is on first-name terms, a strong sense of community prevails.  Evenings often find us gathered at the ends of driveways, sharing stories and laughter as the neighborhood children play amidst their toys, sidewalk chalk masterpieces, and fluttering kites.  It's a refreshing escape from the relentless pace of modern life, a nostalgic glimpse into a simpler time.   

Our peaceful haven is nestled amidst sprawling fields and towering trees, bathed in the warm glow of cerulean skies and fluffy white clouds.  However, this idyllic setting is occasionally disrupted by the threat of severe weather. This season, we've been on high alert for tornadoes, and last night, the dreaded siren wailed, forcing us to seek shelter.  I found myself tucked safely in my bathtub, my smallest dog nestled beside me, along with my purse and a few comforting pillows.  My larger dog, ever the brave soul, remained in the living room, pacing anxiously and letting out nervous barks.  The neighborhood fell silent, save for the relentless drumming of hail against the ground.  The aftermath was a sight to behold – the road literally steamed as the temperature plummeted from a scorching 92 degrees to a cool 75 in mere minutes.  The hail melted instantly upon contact with the hot pavement.  As the storm clouds parted, a breathtaking double rainbow arced across the sky.  I dashed inside, grabbed my camera, and snapped a few pictures to share with loved ones, who marveled at the beauty just as I did.  

The neighborhood remained hushed for another hour before residents slowly returned from their various hiding spots. Life resumed its usual rhythm – mothers and children gathered outdoors, the aroma of dinner wafting through the air.  It's a heartwarming community, a perfect fit for this transplant from New Hampshire.  I adore the lilting cadence of Southern accents and the friendly smiles that greet me everywhere I go.  While all the duplexes appear identical from the outside, each apartment boasts a unique interior.  Some are surprisingly petite, which I find a bit perplexing.  

One of my favorite pastimes is strolling through the expansive field behind my home, meandering down to a picturesque pond, perfect for quiet contemplation.  I've even spotted deer grazing peacefully in the distance, and in the morning, the chorus of a giant bullfrog serenades the waking world.  Living just forty minutes from Charlotte offers the best of both worlds – the tranquility of a small-town community and the convenience of city life.  Each morning is greeted by the cheerful crowing of roosters from nearby farms, a charming reminder of our rural surroundings.  We even have a donkey residing at a neighboring farm, whose braying fills the evening air, a quirky symphony of rural living.  I feel incredibly fortunate to have stumbled upon this hidden gem of a neighborhood.

I moved into this neighborhood right as eighth grade began.  Making friends took a while at first, but I eventually became close with someone just two houses down and another guy on my street. They've both moved away now, but the memories remain.  Most of the people who lived here when I first arrived are still here.  It's pretty typical for an American suburb – lots of two-story houses, kids playing outside whenever the weather's nice, and a quiet atmosphere most days.  I've never had any issues with the neighbors; you're left to your own devices unless you need something, and I've never had a package stolen from my porch. I trust my neighbors. There's a park just a short walk away that holds a lot of memories for me. I played basketball, football, and baseball there with the neighborhood guys.  I even got elbowed in the nose playing football, one of my worst memories, but the good times definitely outweigh the bad. Now, whenever I go to the park, it's to hang out with my cousin's kids. They're much younger than me, but they still love the swings and slides.  Just thinking about the park makes them excited. It brings back a lot of feelings for me.

This neighborhood is pretty diverse, with tons of different food options nearby.  Within a mile, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants.  Although, a lot of people just order takeout through apps like GrubHub and DoorDash these days. The most popular spots are the fast food chains, which you can find in any suburb, and there are plenty of pizza places too.  The stores here have everything you need, including multiple dry cleaners. There's a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, plus a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is a big deal in the Midwest.  There's even an Indian-owned store for those who want to make their own Indian food or grab something ready-made. 

Overall, I really like my neighborhood. Reading about the troubles some people have with their neighbors online and in the news makes me appreciate mine even more.

Johnston, a small town nestled in South Carolina, might not stand out on a map, but it holds a special place in the heart of its community. 
Known as the Peach Capital of the World, the town proudly displays this title on its welcoming sign.  Fields of peach trees and cattle pastures stretch as far as the eye can see, painting a picture of rural life. 

The houses, mostly two-story structures with metal roofs or gray shingles, are spread out across the countryside, often tucked away from the road to create ample space for livestock and crops.  The town center, centered around a single stop light at a four-way intersection, is where you'll find all the essential amenities.  

For a quick bite, residents have a choice of three eateries: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta, a Mexican joint; and Gary's, a local burger chain.  A pizza place once graced the town, but sadly, it closed its doors recently.  Maxwell and Halford Drug, a small, family-owned pharmacy, is a local favorite, particularly for their unique Cherry Coca-Cola.  IGA, a small but pricier grocery store, is the only option for local shopping, though many residents prefer to make the trip to Batesburg-Leesville for their main grocery needs.  

Dollar General, unsurprisingly, reigns supreme as the most popular store, offering a wide variety of everyday necessities and bustling with activity from opening to closing.  Possibilities Furniture & More, a friendly establishment run by a beloved community member, provides a selection of furniture and even offers delivery services.  Attached to the furniture store is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet grooming service that caters to all your furry friend's needs.

Both the doctor's and veterinary practices are located away from the town center, though well-equipped to serve the residents.  Johnston Elementary School provides education for students up to fifth grade, after which they head to the neighboring town for middle and high school.  

While Johnston lacks traditional parks, a 2.5-acre recreational area is currently being developed to offer families more opportunities for outdoor fun and attract new residents. Despite its limited entertainment options, Johnston remains a charming town, small enough to pass by unnoticed, yet brimming with a unique character and strong community spirit.

The first time I heard about my neighborhood, it was on a podcast about missing persons. That was a bit of a shock—almost every apartment in the area costs over a thousand dollars a month.  I'd never heard of that story, and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle everyone faces. I know a few friends who cry themselves to sleep each night. Things are expensive, but we've learned to be thrifty over the years. You start to appreciate the dusty scent of flea market toys and clothes that have been stored away. You smell less as you get older. You might take up smoking, or maybe you just get used to the way things are. But the flea market always finds its way back. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines piled on a closed piano. It settles into the leather and stays there even after you wash it. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can visit two charity thrift shops, a library, a rare book store, and a curiosity shop. Downtown is bustling, with cars and people filling the streets every morning, but you wouldn't hear it in the thrift stores.  No matter how many people or cars pass by, the stores are silent. It's a lovely place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there are more and more of these. Cars and people flood in. It's a developing city, they say.  With one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery headquartered here, it's still growing. It reminds me of New York. Everyone and everything has their own goals, and no one asks much of you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where showing a little concern means you care. People here don't pry into your life. You can keep to yourself as long as you like, and the city will roll on like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment building of strangers and more of a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I try to make sure to clean up after myself and leave them food, and they do the same for me. I bring them their mail, and they bring mine to me. It's nice to see them, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, impersonal modernist complex, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I haven't completely messed up my life.

My neighborhood is like a textbook example of suburban uniformity. The homeowner's association makes sure every house looks the same: manicured lawns, decorative pebbles, and short driveways, all topped off with a two-car garage.  The streets are brand new and spotless, no potholes or cracks in sight.  While most houses are single-story, you'll occasionally find a two-story one sprinkled in.  

Forget about individual mailboxes - we have a communal setup like an apartment complex, with a row of mailboxes at the end of the street that require a key. It's all about that HOA-mandated consistency.

Living on the edge of the city, my neighborhood has a blend of suburban and rural vibes. We have plenty of space, including multiple community pools - well-maintained and gated - and walking trails for your furry friends or a peaceful evening stroll. You don't need a park for exercise; the neighborhood itself is big enough for a good run.

Mostly, the residents are retirees, creating a safe, friendly atmosphere where everyone looks out for each other. There are some middle-aged and young professionals sprinkled in too.

The city itself is surprisingly large, but with a small-town feel. It has all the essentials - think one mall - which isn't huge, but gets the job done. A quick 15-minute drive takes you to a variety of stores, from high-end grocery stores to bargain outlets.

Overall, my neighborhood is safe, well-kept, and pretty typical. We have great amenities, but it's a short drive to any larger shopping centers.

My home is nestled in a small town in the Midwest, just outside the bustling suburbs of a big city. My neighborhood, on the east side of town, is considered one of the less affluent areas, with many homes rented or owned by those with limited means.  While property values are lower, it's not an unpleasant place. The people here are generally friendly – a wave and a hello are common when we're out and about. Crime rates are higher than in other parts of town, though still relatively low. Over the past decade, there have been a few unsettling incidents nearby, including a couple of shootings and even a homicide, a painful reminder of the realities we face. Last year, the family next door lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar, a tragedy that deeply impacted our community. Thankfully, our family hasn't been directly affected by crime beyond the occasional missing item from our porch. 

Our town has been profoundly touched by the opioid epidemic sweeping the nation. Sadly, many lives have been lost to fentanyl overdoses. However, there are glimmers of hope. Our town offers valuable resources to combat this crisis, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training for families affected by this devastating issue.

Despite these challenges, our town has a lot to offer. My son attends a wonderful elementary school with dedicated staff – from the principal to the teachers and support personnel.  He thrives in the positive environment, and hasn't experienced any bullying, even with his special needs. The school actively involves families through its PTO, which organizes numerous events throughout the year to enhance education and foster a sense of community.  Recognizing that over 20% of our town's residents live below the poverty line, the school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring no child goes hungry.  They create an inclusive environment where no one feels "less than" because of their financial situation.  School fees, supplies, and field trip costs are also kept reasonable, making education accessible to all.

While the City Council and staff have made impressive improvements to the town's appearance – repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks – these enhancements seem to be concentrated in the central business district and west side, where most of the shopping and traffic is located. The east side, where I live, has been largely overlooked, a matter of concern for many residents.

Overall, I find joy in living here. The people are friendly, the schools are excellent, we have a good variety of shopping options (both locally owned businesses and larger stores) to meet our needs, and while our home may not be a financial gem, it's comfortable and provides everything we need. We've called this town home for over 16 years, and it's hard to imagine ourselves anywhere else.

My neighborhood is a tapestry of culture, nestled on a hillside surrounded by buildings steeped in history.  I reside in a seven-story apartment building directly across from a venerable, old live theater. A short stroll down the hill leads me to a vibrant arcade bar, a gathering place for a diverse array of souls, especially on warm summer nights when a line often snakes down the block. A few blocks further up the hill, a generous city park offers a respite, enclosed by concrete walls with imposing stairs built into their sides. During the harsh winter months, when temperatures plummet, individuals experiencing homelessness establish neat rows of tents along the sidewalk and up the wide steps. Though snowfall is infrequent, the relentless winter rains test the limits of their resilience. Clustering together in the heart of the city, rather than seeking shelter in the wilds, offers them a modicum of warmth and comfort.  They are also within easy reach of a vital resource: a family center a short distance away, providing access to basic necessities like bathing and showers.

Yet, the allure of my city lies not solely in its historical grandeur – the towering edifices, the architectural wonders that cascade down the hills towards the ocean. It's the indomitable spirit of its people that truly captivates me. Hilltop, once infamous for its gang violence, a dark chapter etched into the city's annals, still echoes with tales of federal agents and the Drug Enforcement Administration, desperately attempting to cleanse the streets three decades ago. These stories, passed down through generations, serve as a stark reminder of a tumultuous past.  The residents, despite the enduring vestiges of that era and the ongoing challenges of urban life, tirelessly strive to maintain their community. They remain fiercely invested in their city, their block, their home. Despite the lingering warnings about venturing out alone after dark, particularly for those who don't share the same skin tone, I believe these cautions are echoes of a bygone era, tinged with the bitterness of societal conditioning. Perhaps it's my complexion, a shade that allows me to blend, or maybe it's the shared awareness of societal ills that binds us together, that Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own. I sense a kinship with those who, like me, are acutely aware of the persistent reminders that haunt our nation: the prejudice, the ingrained biases, the assumptions that stem from ignorance and fear, even in a city that prides itself on its cultural diversity. I know this with unwavering certainty: no matter where life's journey may take me, Hilltop will always be my home.

Walking those streets at night, I feel a surge of aliveness, encountering individuals who have extended kindness and compassion more readily than aggression. This is a place where laundromat owners have extended their hours to accommodate my need for a charged phone during a sudden downpour. It's a place where I've found solace huddling against cold, concrete storefronts on bleak nights, only to be met with a kind smile, a five-dollar bill, and words of affirmation.

My life is nestled in the heart of rural Michigan, a place where rolling farmland gives way to quaint tourist towns. It's a world away from bustling cities, with no towering malls or familiar chains like Walmart or Target. Getting around means relying on the open road, but the journey is always worth it.  I live surrounded by breathtaking beauty – Lake Michigan to one side, Lake Charlevoix on the other. Beaches are just a stone's throw away, inviting you to dip your toes in the refreshing water.

Our neighborhood embodies the true spirit of small-town life. Houses aren't crammed together, each one unique and reflecting the stories of those who live within. Some have been lovingly updated, while others retain their timeless charm. Many boast full basements, visible from the street, and the homes sport a colorful range of aluminum siding, a nod to a bygone era.

It's a place where families thrive. Yards are havens of laughter, filled with trampolines, swings, gardens, and the occasional fence for furry friends. The people here are hard-working, dedicated to their families and their community. You'll see children chasing each other down the sidewalks, dogs being walked, and neighbors biking and rollerblading. 

There's a sense of belonging here. You know your neighbors, and you know who is part of the fabric of our community. A wave from someone grilling on their porch, a friendly smile from someone walking their dog down the street – these are the everyday gestures that make this place so special.

The lawns are meticulously kept, a testament to the pride residents take in their homes. The air is clean and fresh, and the pace of life is slower, more deliberate. It's not a neighborhood that boasts extravagant mansions, but one that whispers of warmth, safety, and a sense of belonging. It's a place where you can truly put down roots and build a life you love.

Within walking distance, you'll find the county sheriff's department, the health department, and the recycling center – all testaments to the strong community spirit. Nearby baseball and softball fields echo with the cheers of players and fans, while the rumble of small planes taking off and landing at our little airport fills the air. A local ice cream shop is a short stroll away, and a trip downtown is easily accomplished on foot or bike.

Our park is just eight blocks away, a haven for children and adults alike. This is truly a great place to call home, a place where life is simple, genuine, and filled with the warmth of community.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low.
